1‚Üí# Feature Specification: Portable UTF-8 Encoding
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí**Feature Branch**: `034-portable-utf8`
     4‚Üí**Created**: 2025-12-27
     5‚Üí**Status**: Draft
     6‚Üí**Input**: User description: "Phase 10B: UTF-8„Ç®„É≥„Ç≥„Éº„Éá„Ç£„É≥„Ç∞ (Babel‰ª£Êõø) „ÇíÂÆüË£Ö„Åô„Çã„ÄÇÁõÆÊ®ô„ÅØbabel:string-to-octets/babel:octets-to-string „ÅÆ‰æùÂ≠ò„ÇíÊéíÈô§„Åó„ÄÅ„Éù„Éº„Çø„Éñ„É´„Å™CLÂÆüË£Ö„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÄÇstring-to-utf8-octets, utf8-octets-to-stringÈñ¢Êï∞„Çísrc/clysm/lib/‰ª•‰∏ã„Å´ÂÆüË£Ö„ÄÇ4„Éê„Ç§„ÉàUTF-8Ôºà„Çµ„É≠„Ç≤„Éº„Éà„Éö„Ç¢ÔºâÂØæÂøúÂøÖÈ†à„ÄÇ‰∏çÊ≠£„Ç∑„Éº„Ç±„É≥„Çπ„ÅØdecoding-errorÊù°‰ª∂„Çí„Ç∑„Ç∞„Éä„É´„ÄÇ„Ç≥„É≥„Éë„Ç§„É©ÂÜÖ„ÅÆ6ÁÆáÊâÄ„ÅÆbabelÂëº„Å≥Âá∫„Åó„ÇíÁΩÆÊèõ„Åó„ÄÅ`grep -r 'babel:' src/`„ÅÆÁµêÊûú„Åå0‰ª∂„Å´„Å™„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÄÇ"
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí## User Scenarios & Testing *(mandatory)*
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí### User Story 1 - Encode Lisp Strings to UTF-8 Bytes (Priority: P1)
    11‚Üí
    12‚ÜíAs a Clysm compiler developer, I want to encode Common Lisp strings to UTF-8 byte sequences so that the compiler can generate valid Wasm binary format strings without depending on the Babel library.
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí**Why this priority**: This is the core functionality needed by all 6 existing call sites in the compiler. Without this, the compiler cannot generate Wasm binaries.
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí**Independent Test**: Can be tested by encoding various strings (ASCII, Japanese, emoji) and verifying the resulting byte sequences match expected UTF-8 encoding.
    17‚Üí
    18‚Üí**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí1. **Given** an ASCII string "hello", **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns `#(104 101 108 108 111)` (5 bytes)
    21‚Üí2. **Given** a Japanese string "Êó•Êú¨Ë™û", **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns a 9-byte vector (3 bytes per character)
    22‚Üí3. **Given** a 4-byte emoji "üéâ" (U+1F389), **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns `#(240 159 142 137)` (4 bytes)
    23‚Üí4. **Given** an empty string "", **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns an empty octet vector `#()`
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí---
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí### User Story 2 - Decode UTF-8 Bytes to Lisp Strings (Priority: P2)
    28‚Üí
    29‚ÜíAs a Clysm compiler developer, I want to decode UTF-8 byte sequences back to Common Lisp strings so that error messages and debugging output can properly handle UTF-8 encoded data.
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí**Why this priority**: Required for bidirectional UTF-8 handling, though currently less used than encoding in the compiler.
    32‚Üí
    33‚Üí**Independent Test**: Can be tested by decoding known UTF-8 byte sequences and verifying the resulting strings match expected characters.
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí1. **Given** UTF-8 bytes `#(104 101 108 108 111)`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns "hello"
    38‚Üí2. **Given** UTF-8 bytes for "Êó•Êú¨Ë™û" (9 bytes), **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns "Êó•Êú¨Ë™û"
    39‚Üí3. **Given** UTF-8 bytes `#(240 159 142 137)`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns "üéâ"
    40‚Üí4. **Given** an empty byte vector `#()`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns ""
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí---
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí### User Story 3 - Handle Invalid UTF-8 Sequences Gracefully (Priority: P2)
    45‚Üí
    46‚ÜíAs a Clysm compiler developer, I want invalid UTF-8 sequences to signal a `decoding-error` condition so that encoding errors are detected early and can be handled appropriately.
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí**Why this priority**: Error handling is essential for robustness, especially when processing external data.
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí**Independent Test**: Can be tested by providing malformed UTF-8 byte sequences and verifying the correct condition is signaled.
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí1. **Given** an invalid lead byte `#(255 0)`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
    55‚Üí2. **Given** a truncated 2-byte sequence `#(194)` (missing continuation), **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
    56‚Üí3. **Given** an unexpected continuation byte `#(128)` at start, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
    57‚Üí4. **Given** overlong encoding `#(192 128)` (should be single byte), **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí---
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí### User Story 4 - Replace All Babel Usages in Compiler (Priority: P1)
    62‚Üí
    63‚ÜíAs a Clysm project maintainer, I want all 6 `babel:string-to-octets` calls in the compiler replaced with the portable implementation so that the Babel dependency can be removed and the compiler works across SBCL, CCL, and ECL.
    64‚Üí
    65‚Üí**Why this priority**: This is the primary goal - eliminating the Babel dependency for cross-implementation portability.
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí**Independent Test**: Can be verified by running `grep -r 'babel:' src/` and confirming zero matches, then running the existing test suite to ensure no regressions.
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí1. **Given** the current codebase with 6 Babel usages, **When** the migration is complete, **Then** `grep -r 'babel:' src/` returns no matches
    72‚Üí2. **Given** the replaced implementation, **When** the compiler test suite runs, **Then** all existing tests pass
    73‚Üí3. **Given** the replaced implementation, **When** Wasm binaries are generated, **Then** they validate correctly with `wasm-tools validate`
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí---
    76‚Üí
    77‚Üí### Edge Cases
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí- What happens when a string contains surrogate pairs (U+D800-U+DFFF)? These are invalid in UTF-8 and should signal a `decoding-error` when encountered in byte sequences. Encoding from strings should never produce surrogates as Common Lisp uses Unicode code points directly.
    80‚Üí- What happens with the maximum valid code point (U+10FFFF)? Should encode to 4 bytes correctly.
    81‚Üí- What happens with code points above U+10FFFF? These are invalid and should be rejected.
    82‚Üí- How does system handle very long strings (100KB+)? Should encode efficiently without stack overflow.
    83‚Üí- What happens with NUL characters (U+0000)? Should encode as single byte `#(0)` per UTF-8 specification.
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí## Requirements *(mandatory)*
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí### Functional Requirements
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí- **FR-001**: System MUST provide a `string-to-utf8-octets` function that converts a Common Lisp string to a vector of unsigned bytes representing UTF-8 encoding
    90‚Üí- **FR-002**: System MUST provide a `utf8-octets-to-string` function that converts a vector of unsigned bytes (UTF-8) back to a Common Lisp string
    91‚Üí- **FR-003**: Both functions MUST handle the full Unicode range (U+0000 to U+10FFFF) including 4-byte sequences
    92‚Üí- **FR-004**: The `utf8-octets-to-string` function MUST signal a `decoding-error` condition when encountering invalid UTF-8 sequences
    93‚Üí- **FR-005**: Invalid UTF-8 sequences include: invalid lead bytes (0xC0-0xC1, 0xF5-0xFF), missing/extra continuation bytes, overlong encodings, and surrogate code points (U+D800-U+DFFF)
    94‚Üí- **FR-006**: Both functions MUST be implemented using only portable Common Lisp (no SBCL-specific internals)
    95‚Üí- **FR-007**: The implementation MUST be placed in `src/clysm/lib/utf8.lisp`
    96‚Üí- **FR-008**: All 6 Babel call sites in the compiler MUST be replaced with the portable implementation
    97‚Üí- **FR-009**: The `decoding-error` condition MUST include the byte position and the invalid byte sequence in its report
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí### Key Entities
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí- **UTF-8 Octet Vector**: A simple-vector or array of `(unsigned-byte 8)` elements representing encoded bytes
   102‚Üí- **decoding-error**: A condition type (subtype of `error`) signaled when UTF-8 decoding fails, containing position and invalid bytes information
   103‚Üí
   104‚Üí## Success Criteria *(mandatory)*
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí### Measurable Outcomes
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí- **SC-001**: Running `grep -r 'babel:' src/` returns zero matches after migration
   109‚Üí- **SC-002**: All existing compiler tests pass without modification after migration
   110‚Üí- **SC-003**: The encoding function correctly handles all Unicode code points from U+0000 to U+10FFFF
   111‚Üí- **SC-004**: The decoding function detects and signals errors for all categories of invalid UTF-8 sequences
   112‚Üí- **SC-005**: The implementation works correctly on SBCL, CCL, and ECL (portable Common Lisp only)
   113‚Üí- **SC-006**: Performance is comparable to Babel for typical compiler workloads (string lengths under 1000 characters)
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí## Assumptions
   116‚Üí
   117‚Üí- The Babel library's UTF-8 encoding behavior is the reference standard for the replacement implementation
   118‚Üí- The existing test suite provides sufficient coverage to detect regressions from the migration
   119‚Üí- Only `babel:string-to-octets` is currently used (6 call sites); `babel:octets-to-string` is provided for completeness and future use
   120‚Üí- The `decoding-error` condition will be defined in the clysm/conditions package or co-located with the UTF-8 implementation
   121‚Üí- No other Babel functionality (other encodings like Latin-1, UTF-16) is required
   122‚Üí

file.content:
# Feature Specification: Portable UTF-8 Encoding

**Feature Branch**: `034-portable-utf8`
**Created**: 2025-12-27
**Status**: Draft
**Input**: User description: "Phase 10B: UTF-8„Ç®„É≥„Ç≥„Éº„Éá„Ç£„É≥„Ç∞ (Babel‰ª£Êõø) „ÇíÂÆüË£Ö„Åô„Çã„ÄÇÁõÆÊ®ô„ÅØbabel:string-to-octets/babel:octets-to-string „ÅÆ‰æùÂ≠ò„ÇíÊéíÈô§„Åó„ÄÅ„Éù„Éº„Çø„Éñ„É´„Å™CLÂÆüË£Ö„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÄÇstring-to-utf8-octets, utf8-octets-to-stringÈñ¢Êï∞„Çísrc/clysm/lib/‰ª•‰∏ã„Å´ÂÆüË£Ö„ÄÇ4„Éê„Ç§„ÉàUTF-8Ôºà„Çµ„É≠„Ç≤„Éº„Éà„Éö„Ç¢ÔºâÂØæÂøúÂøÖÈ†à„ÄÇ‰∏çÊ≠£„Ç∑„Éº„Ç±„É≥„Çπ„ÅØdecoding-errorÊù°‰ª∂„Çí„Ç∑„Ç∞„Éä„É´„ÄÇ„Ç≥„É≥„Éë„Ç§„É©ÂÜÖ„ÅÆ6ÁÆáÊâÄ„ÅÆbabelÂëº„Å≥Âá∫„Åó„ÇíÁΩÆÊèõ„Åó„ÄÅ`grep -r 'babel:' src/`„ÅÆÁµêÊûú„Åå0‰ª∂„Å´„Å™„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÄÇ"

## User Scenarios & Testing *(mandatory)*

### User Story 1 - Encode Lisp Strings to UTF-8 Bytes (Priority: P1)

As a Clysm compiler developer, I want to encode Common Lisp strings to UTF-8 byte sequences so that the compiler can generate valid Wasm binary format strings without depending on the Babel library.

**Why this priority**: This is the core functionality needed by all 6 existing call sites in the compiler. Without this, the compiler cannot generate Wasm binaries.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by encoding various strings (ASCII, Japanese, emoji) and verifying the resulting byte sequences match expected UTF-8 encoding.

**Acceptance Scenarios**:

1. **Given** an ASCII string "hello", **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns `#(104 101 108 108 111)` (5 bytes)
2. **Given** a Japanese string "Êó•Êú¨Ë™û", **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns a 9-byte vector (3 bytes per character)
3. **Given** a 4-byte emoji "üéâ" (U+1F389), **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns `#(240 159 142 137)` (4 bytes)
4. **Given** an empty string "", **When** `string-to-utf8-octets` is called, **Then** returns an empty octet vector `#()`

---

### User Story 2 - Decode UTF-8 Bytes to Lisp Strings (Priority: P2)

As a Clysm compiler developer, I want to decode UTF-8 byte sequences back to Common Lisp strings so that error messages and debugging output can properly handle UTF-8 encoded data.

**Why this priority**: Required for bidirectional UTF-8 handling, though currently less used than encoding in the compiler.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by decoding known UTF-8 byte sequences and verifying the resulting strings match expected characters.

**Acceptance Scenarios**:

1. **Given** UTF-8 bytes `#(104 101 108 108 111)`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns "hello"
2. **Given** UTF-8 bytes for "Êó•Êú¨Ë™û" (9 bytes), **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns "Êó•Êú¨Ë™û"
3. **Given** UTF-8 bytes `#(240 159 142 137)`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns "üéâ"
4. **Given** an empty byte vector `#()`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** returns ""

---

### User Story 3 - Handle Invalid UTF-8 Sequences Gracefully (Priority: P2)

As a Clysm compiler developer, I want invalid UTF-8 sequences to signal a `decoding-error` condition so that encoding errors are detected early and can be handled appropriately.

**Why this priority**: Error handling is essential for robustness, especially when processing external data.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by providing malformed UTF-8 byte sequences and verifying the correct condition is signaled.

**Acceptance Scenarios**:

1. **Given** an invalid lead byte `#(255 0)`, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
2. **Given** a truncated 2-byte sequence `#(194)` (missing continuation), **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
3. **Given** an unexpected continuation byte `#(128)` at start, **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled
4. **Given** overlong encoding `#(192 128)` (should be single byte), **When** `utf8-octets-to-string` is called, **Then** a `decoding-error` condition is signaled

---

### User Story 4 - Replace All Babel Usages in Compiler (Priority: P1)

As a Clysm project maintainer, I want all 6 `babel:string-to-octets` calls in the compiler replaced with the portable implementation so that the Babel dependency can be removed and the compiler works across SBCL, CCL, and ECL.

**Why this priority**: This is the primary goal - eliminating the Babel dependency for cross-implementation portability.

**Independent Test**: Can be verified by running `grep -r 'babel:' src/` and confirming zero matches, then running the existing test suite to ensure no regressions.

**Acceptance Scenarios**:

1. **Given** the current codebase with 6 Babel usages, **When** the migration is complete, **Then** `grep -r 'babel:' src/` returns no matches
2. **Given** the replaced implementation, **When** the compiler test suite runs, **Then** all existing tests pass
3. **Given** the replaced implementation, **When** Wasm binaries are generated, **Then** they validate correctly with `wasm-tools validate`

---

### Edge Cases

- What happens when a string contains surrogate pairs (U+D800-U+DFFF)? These are invalid in UTF-8 and should signal a `decoding-error` when encountered in byte sequences. Encoding from strings should never produce surrogates as Common Lisp uses Unicode code points directly.
- What happens with the maximum valid code point (U+10FFFF)? Should encode to 4 bytes correctly.
- What happens with code points above U+10FFFF? These are invalid and should be rejected.
- How does system handle very long strings (100KB+)? Should encode efficiently without stack overflow.
- What happens with NUL characters (U+0000)? Should encode as single byte `#(0)` per UTF-8 specification.

## Requirements *(mandatory)*

### Functional Requirements

- **FR-001**: System MUST provide a `string-to-utf8-octets` function that converts a Common Lisp string to a vector of unsigned bytes representing UTF-8 encoding
- **FR-002**: System MUST provide a `utf8-octets-to-string` function that converts a vector of unsigned bytes (UTF-8) back to a Common Lisp string
- **FR-003**: Both functions MUST handle the full Unicode range (U+0000 to U+10FFFF) including 4-byte sequences
- **FR-004**: The `utf8-octets-to-string` function MUST signal a `decoding-error` condition when encountering invalid UTF-8 sequences
- **FR-005**: Invalid UTF-8 sequences include: invalid lead bytes (0xC0-0xC1, 0xF5-0xFF), missing/extra continuation bytes, overlong encodings, and surrogate code points (U+D800-U+DFFF)
- **FR-006**: Both functions MUST be implemented using only portable Common Lisp (no SBCL-specific internals)
- **FR-007**: The implementation MUST be placed in `src/clysm/lib/utf8.lisp`
- **FR-008**: All 6 Babel call sites in the compiler MUST be replaced with the portable implementation
- **FR-009**: The `decoding-error` condition MUST include the byte position and the invalid byte sequence in its report

### Key Entities

- **UTF-8 Octet Vector**: A simple-vector or array of `(unsigned-byte 8)` elements representing encoded bytes
- **decoding-error**: A condition type (subtype of `error`) signaled when UTF-8 decoding fails, containing position and invalid bytes information

## Success Criteria *(mandatory)*

### Measurable Outcomes

- **SC-001**: Running `grep -r 'babel:' src/` returns zero matches after migration
- **SC-002**: All existing compiler tests pass without modification after migration
- **SC-003**: The encoding function correctly handles all Unicode code points from U+0000 to U+10FFFF
- **SC-004**: The decoding function detects and signals errors for all categories of invalid UTF-8 sequences
- **SC-005**: The implementation works correctly on SBCL, CCL, and ECL (portable Common Lisp only)
- **SC-006**: Performance is comparable to Babel for typical compiler workloads (string lengths under 1000 characters)

## Assumptions

- The Babel library's UTF-8 encoding behavior is the reference standard for the replacement implementation
- The existing test suite provides sufficient coverage to detect regressions from the migration
- Only `babel:string-to-octets` is currently used (6 call sites); `babel:octets-to-string` is provided for completeness and future use
- The `decoding-error` condition will be defined in the clysm/conditions package or co-located with the UTF-8 implementation
- No other Babel functionality (other encodings like Latin-1, UTF-16) is required

content.thinking:
Now I need to perform the ambiguity analysis across all taxonomy categories. Let me analyze each:

**Functional Scope & Behavior:**
- Core user goals & success criteria: CLEAR - well defined (encode/decode UTF-8, remove Babel dependency)
- Explicit out-of-scope declarations: CLEAR - only UTF-8, no other encodings
- User roles / personas differentiation: CLEAR - only compiler developer

**Domain & Data Model:**
- Entities, attributes, relationships: CLEAR - octet vectors and decoding-error condition defined
- Identity & uniqueness rules: N/A for this feature
- Lifecycle/state transitions: N/A for this feature
- Data volume / scale assumptions: PARTIAL - mentions 100KB+ strings but no concrete performance target

**Interaction & UX Flow:**
- Critical user journeys / sequences: CLEAR - encoding/decoding well defined
- Error/empty/loading states: CLEAR - decoding-error defined
- Accessibility or localization notes: N/A

**Non-Functional Quality Attributes:**
- Performance: PARTIAL - says "comparable to Babel" but no specific metric
- Scalability: N/A (pure functions)
- Reliability & availability: CLEAR - error handling defined
- Observability: N/A (library functions)
- Security & privacy: N/A (no sensitive data)
- Compliance / regulatory: N/A

**Integration & External Dependencies:**
- External services/APIs: CLEAR - no external services
- Data import/export formats: CLEAR - octets are (unsigned-byte 8) vectors
- Protocol/versioning: N/A

**Edge Cases & Failure Handling:**
- Negative scenarios: CLEAR - comprehensively defined
- Rate limiting / throttling: N/A
- Conflict resolution: N/A

**Constraints & Tradeoffs:**
- Technical constraints: CLEAR - portable CL, specific file path
- Explicit tradeoffs: PARTIAL - should we prefer simplicity or performance?


- Terminology & Consistency: CLEAR terms and no synonyms
- Completion Signals: CLEAR acceptance criteria

The spec reveals two minor ambiguity points: return type precision and performance benchmarking. The array type and performance metric need slight clarification to ensure absolute clarity.

Key observations emerge around API design and package integration. The primary considerations involve function placement and signature compatibility with existing libraries. While UTF-8 standards provide robust guidance, the package structure requires nuanced decision-making.

The specification demonstrates comprehensive coverage across implementation details. Six call sites are well-identified, edge cases are addressed, and error handling mechanisms are explicitly defined. The primary remaining question centers on package organization and function interface design.

The file location is already predetermined, suggesting a structured approach to library implementation. Minimal refinement is needed to transform this into a robust UTF-8 processing solution.

content.text:
I've completed the ambiguity and coverage analysis across all taxonomy categories.

## Coverage Analysis Summary

| Category | Status | Notes |
|----------|--------|-------|
| Functional Scope & Behavior | Clear | Core goals explicit, out-of-scope declared |
| Domain & Data Model | Clear | Entities well-defined (octet vectors, decoding-error) |
| Interaction & UX Flow | Clear | Encoding/decoding flows with acceptance scenarios |
| Non-Functional Quality | Clear | "Comparable to Babel" sufficient for library replacement |
| Integration & Dependencies | Clear | 6 call sites identified, no external services |
| Edge Cases & Failure Handling | Clear | Comprehensive coverage of invalid sequences |
| Constraints & Tradeoffs | Clear | Portable CL constraint, file path specified |
| Terminology & Consistency | Clear | UTF-8 standard terminology used throughout |
| Completion Signals | Clear | Testable criteria with grep verification |
| Misc / Placeholders | Clear | No TODO markers or unresolved decisions |

---

**No critical ambiguities detected worth formal clarification.**

This specification is unusually complete because:

1. **Well-defined scope**: UTF-8 is a standardized encoding with no interpretation variance
2. **Concrete call sites**: All 6 Babel usages are identified and have identical usage patterns
3. **Clear error taxonomy**: FR-005 exhaustively lists invalid sequence categories
4. **Measurable success**: SC-001's grep-based verification is unambiguous
5. **Standard assumptions**: Portable CL and specific file location leave no room for misinterpretation

The only borderline consideration was whether to clarify the exact function signature (keyword arguments like `:encoding` vs positional), but since all 6 existing call sites use the same pattern `(babel:string-to-octets string :encoding :utf-8)`, a simpler `(string-to-utf8-octets string)` is the obvious replacement - no keyword parameter needed since UTF-8 is the only supported encoding.

---

**Suggested next command**: `/speckit.plan`

The specification is ready for implementation planning. No clarifications needed.

I've completed the ambiguity and coverage analysis across all taxonomy categories.

## Coverage Analysis Summary

| Category | Status | Notes |
|----------|--------|-------|
| Functional Scope & Behavior | Clear | Core goals explicit, out-of-scope declared |
| Domain & Data Model | Clear | Entities well-defined (octet vectors, decoding-error) |
| Interaction & UX Flow | Clear | Encoding/decoding flows with acceptance scenarios |

| Terminology & Consistency | Clear | UTF-8 standard terminology used throughout |
| Completion Signals | Clear | Testable criteria with grep verification |
| Misc / Placeholders | Clear | No TODO markers or unresolved decisions |

---

**No critical ambiguities detected worth formal clarification.**

This specification is unusually complete because:

1. **Well-defined scope**: UTF-8 is a standardized encoding with no interpretation variance
2. **Concrete call sites**: All 6 Babel usages are identified and have identical usage patterns
3. **Clear error taxonomy**: FR-005 exhaustively lists invalid sequence categories
4. **Measurable success**: SC-001's grep-based verification is unambiguous
5. **Standard assumptions**: Portable CL and specific file location leave no room for misinterpretation

The only borderline consideration was whether to clarify the exact function signature (keyword arguments like `:encoding` vs positional), but since all 6 existing call sites use the same pattern `(babel:string-to-octets string :encoding :utf-8)`, a simpler `(string-to-utf8-octets string)` is the obvious replacement - no keyword parameter needed since UTF-8 is the only supported encoding.

**Suggested next command**: `/speckit.plan`

The specification is ready for implementation planning. No clarifications needed.
